awd_titl_txt: PIRE: Centennial Genetic and Species Transformations in the Epicenter of Marine Biodiversity
awd_abstract_narration:
Kent Carpenter (PI), Daniel Barshis (Old Dominion University), Christopher Bird (Texas A&M University - Corpus Christi), Malin Pinsky (Rutgers University), Beth Polidoro (Arizona State University)

One of the greatest challenges facing humanity today is our ability to understand the impacts humans have on the natural resources we rely on for our existence. Understanding the impacts to date will allow us to better conserve and protect  vital resources for future use. Choosing a successful resource management strategy ensures sustainability of resources for present and future generations. Exponential human population growth over the past century has been accompanied by unprecedented demands on the earth's resources, particularly marine fisheries resources. Fortunately, there exists a large collection of fishes at the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History that offers a unique window into the human impacts on marine fishes over the past century. In 1907-1909, not long after the U.S. colonized the Philippines, our government sent an expedition there to take stock of their natural resources. This was at a time when natural history collections were stored solely in alcohol which preserves DNA over long periods (compared to most museum collections preserved in formalin that alters DNA).  Extensive collections were made that will allow us to examine the changes in the dynamics of populations over a period of extreme human population growth and exploitation of these resources. We will do this by comparing historical and contemporary collections using cutting-edge advanced genomics methods initially developed for human medicine. No work of this scale has ever been accomplished on heavily exploited fisheries and not only will it give us insights valuable for Philippine resource management, but it will also help us understand impacts in other parts of the world. Results will be made available to relevant institutions and the public through extensive outreach activities. This project will integrate field and laboratory research objectives with annual semester-long academic activities in the Philippines. These activities will train a significant number of American and Filipino undergraduate and graduate students and early career professionals in advanced genomic methodology and marine ecology. It will also foster long term collaborative ties and good will between our countries.  

An opportunity to dramatically increase the knowledge of genome-scale evolution in marine fishes over the past century of intense human impacts is possible through a unique and extensive collection from the Philippines that took place from 1907 to 1909 on board the US Research Vessel Albatross, maintained at the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History. The overarching research question in this study is: what genetic and species-level changes have taken place over the past century of intense fisheries exploitation and habitat degradation in the Philippine global epicenter of marine biodiversity? This project takes advantage of the extensive historical collections unique to the Philippines and essential collaborations with Philippine scientists to address the following novel scientific questions: 1. To what extent has genetic diversity been lost from marine species in the Philippines? 2. Have overfishing and habitat loss reduced gene flow between marine populations? 3. To what extent do genetic diversity and species diversity reveal similar changes over a century of human impacts? This will be accomplished by measuring the centennial scale changes in the evolutionary potential of at least 20 species of marine fishes by comparing the genetic makeup of historical and contemporary populations from the same localities using advanced genomic methodologies. The genomic impacts will be compared to larger scale biodiversity changes using 1970's collections of Philippine marine fishes that will be replicated to directly measure species and community scale changes. Together, these investigations will give unprecedented insight into anthropogenic impacts on marine biodiversity and evolution.

por.por_cntn:
The PIRE (Partnerships for International Research and Education) project, titled "PIRE: Centennial Genetic and Species Transformations in the Epicenter of Marine Biodiversity," embarked on an ambitious journey to understand the changes in marine fish biodiversity over a century of intense fisheries and habitat changes in the Philippines. This initiative was a collaborative effort spanning multiple institutions, including Old Dominion University, Rutgers University, Texas A&M University-Corpus Christi, Arizona State University, and Silliman University in the Philippines, along with various other partners. 

The project focused on analyzing historical and contemporary collections to identify genetic- and community-level changes over the past 100 and 40 years, respectively. This period marked significant environmental and anthropogenic changes impacting marine ecosystems, particularly in the Coral Triangle, a region known for its unparalleled marine diversity. The team employed advanced genomic methods to sequence DNA from historical specimens collected by the USS Albatross in the early 1900s and compared these with contemporary samples from the same species and locations. 

One of the significant achievements of the project was the successful extraction and sequencing of DNA from century-old specimens, a feat seldom accomplished in non-model species with limited genomic resources. This breakthrough has implications beyond this project, offering a methodology for future studies involving century-old ethanol-preserved specimens. It also highlights the project's intellectual merit in pioneering techniques for unlocking the genetic secrets of historical museum specimens. 

The project's broader impacts are manifold. It provided invaluable insights into how marine populations have evolved in response to fishing pressure and environmental changes, thus informing conservation strategies and sustainable fisheries management. The research findings suggest that many fish populations have experienced declines in genetic diversity over the past century, possibly impacting their adaptive potential and resilience to environmental changes. Additionally, results have revealed genetic structure across different bioregions from the Philippines for both contemporary and historical populations of Spratelloides delicatulus, a fisheries species that is consumed and used as bait. The observed patterns of temporal and geographic divergence will provide information crucial for the conservation and management of this and other commercially important marine fishes.  

Moreover, the project significantly contributed to human resource development in science and technology. It offered a rich international research experience for undergraduate and graduate students, including those from underrepresented groups. These students gained hands-on experience in cutting-edge genomic research and bioinformatics, fostering a new generation of scientists equipped to tackle global biodiversity challenges. The partnership with Filipino institutions also strengthened international scientific collaboration and capacity building in marine biodiversity research. 

In terms of educational impacts, the project enriched the learning experiences of students and researchers through workshops, conferences, and symposia. These events facilitated knowledge exchange and fostered a deeper understanding of marine biodiversity's complexities and the importance of preserving it. 

The project's infrastructure impacts are notable as well. Silliman University expanded its facilities to support the project, leaving a legacy in the form of enhanced research capacities. Similarly, the collaboration with the Old Dominion University High-Performance Computing Cluster expanded computational resources necessary for processing and analyzing large genomic datasets. 

In conclusion, the PIRE project made substantial contributions to understanding marine biodiversity's genetic transformations over a century. Its findings not only advance scientific knowledge but also provide crucial insights for biodiversity conservation and sustainable resource management. The project stands as a testament to the power of international collaboration in addressing complex global challenges and highlights the importance of integrating historical data to understand the full spectrum of environmental change.
